awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Researching How You Teach Holistic Modeling
awd_abstract_narration:
Models are a critical part of the analysis and design of engineered systems. The purpose of multiple types of models (physical, mathematical, computational, and financial) is to provide a simplified representation of reality that mimics the features of the engineered system, and that predicts the behavior of the system. This project, a collaboration between Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University, San Jose State University, and the University of Louisville, aims to improve engineering students' modeling competence.  The project plans to achieve this goal by transforming first-year engineering courses to teach modeling as an engineering tool. The project will change existing course materials, pedagogy, and assessment methods across the three institutions. Each institution will implement its own specific strategy to teach mathematical, physical, computational, and financial modeling, thus providing three different approaches.  By comparing student's modeling abilities across the institutions and approaches, the project aims to identify the most impactful approaches for teaching multiple modeling in introductory undergraduate engineering courses.

The project is guided by a "holistic modeling perspective" theoretical framework, that builds on the successful "Models and Modeling Perspective" and "Computational Adaptive Expertise" frameworks.  The objectives of the project are to: (1) implement, test, and refine holistic modeling environments for institutions that have flexibility in changing curriculum and for instructors that have different degrees of interest in changing their course(s); (2) implement, test, and refine methods to assess students' modeling abilities; and (3) evaluate and present the results of modeling abilities attained by students at three different universities. A unified language and discussion around modeling will be adopted in all revised courses. An assessment tool to measure students' modeling competence will be developed and implemented at each university. This work builds upon existing research in the development of more easily adaptable and adoptable modeling pedagogies and modeling languages. The following broad research question guides the research: How do students' definitional knowledge, ability to apply, and ability to create models change based on different degrees of modeling integration in the classroom?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Building and applying models is a fundamental part of engineering. Models are used to provide a simplified representation of reality that mimics the features of an engineered system and make predictions about the behavior of the system. There are many different types of engineering models. The main categories based on literature review and research conducted throughout this project are: (1) physical models, (2) engineering drawings and computer-aided design (CAD) models, (3) mathematical models, (4) computational models, and (5) business, entrepreneurial, and financial models. 

 

This project was a collaboration between Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (ERAU), San Jose State University (SJSU), and the University of Louisville (UL). Reflection on theory of change, led the team to develop a plan to implement different modeling interventions at each university that require different levels of time commitment and faculty/program level buy-in. All three institutions had at least one required first-year engineering (FYE) course. At least one of these courses at each university was revised to implement a modeling intervention. All three FYE courses at ERAU were significantly revised to implement new modeling problems, design projects utilizing various modeling tools and tasks, and explicit language about model types. These changes required program-level buy-in, a significant amount of time, and on-going faculty commitment. The only FYE course at SJSU that consisted of design projects revised one of the existing projects to implement various different types of modeling tasks throughout. This change required flexibility in selecting design projects and time to develop a new design project. One of the two FYE courses at UL was revised to incorporate explicit language about model types wherever relevant in the current curriculum. This change did not require changing any of the existing curriculum, rather only adding explicit mention to models where they already exist, so any faculty member could implement this in their course without a program-level change and with minimal time commitment. 

There was an assortment of data collected throughout this project, including think-aloud protocols, students’ works completed on multiple phases of modeling problems, and survey data. The team developed a Modeling Survey tool to investigate students’ perceptions of types of models in STEM fields, along with their descriptions and ideas of how they would apply various engineering models. This survey tool has been included in some of our papers. 

Students completed the Modeling Survey at the beginning and end of the semester at all three institutions in courses with modeling interventions. The analysis of this data helped the team highlight some of the benefits and shortcomings of the interventions at each university.

Key findings:

  • Student awareness of model types improved in all courses with modeling interventions regardless of the type/extent of the intervention. Where assessed, this awareness was also retained across semesters.

  • Ensuring that language is clear when explicitly teaching modeling is critical. We at times used the term “Graphical Models” to categorize engineering drawings and CAD models, but many students confused this with graphing and data representation. Based on our experiences, anecdotal evidence, and data analysis, we suggest the five main categories with the language presented above.

  • Modeling is a specific part of the engineering design and problem solving process, which was found to be difficult to assess within a revised Playground Problem. 

  • Alternatively, a survey (given at the beginning and end of the semester) was effective at assessing student awareness of model types, purpose of models in STEM, and application of models in specific problem scenarios.

  • It was found that the type of course (programming, CAD, design) seemed to have an impact on students’ responses about types of models in the pre-survey (beginning of the semester). Some courses had more impact on different types of models in the post-survey, but all courses had an overall increase in average number of models identified by students in post-survey.

  • Using a guided modeling problem based on model-eliciting activityies (MEAs) and model-adaptation activities (MAAs) improved students’ modeling abilities in a programming course.

    • The team initially tested using one problem with four submissions requiring two written descriptions (mathematical model) and two coded solutions (computational model) (1.written, 2.code, 3.written, 4.code) (1&2 were developed using a small data set, 3&4 students revised models using a larger data set)

    • Since there was regularly a huge decrease in the quality of students’ solutions from written to coded submissions, the team modified the assignment. These three submissions were found to be more effective and more manageable to provide feedback on: 1.written description -mathematical model, 2.algorithm -flow chart or plan for coding, 3.coded solution -computational model (increasing the data set for each submission).

      • Utilizing modeling problems with these three clear phases (solution on paper, plan for coding, coded solution) helped students develop mathematical and computational modeling skills, improved their ability to code, and presented an effective way for faculty to evaluate where students struggled in a programming course.
